quoteTime: About four o’clock that afternoon
quoteLast: the four returned. They must have listened for some time to the conversation between Dawa and myself, for as soon as they entered the tent, the most wicked of the three brothers severely scolded Dawa for flirting with a man. Upon this, the girl’s father at once took her side, and snappishly told his brother that his Dawa had a father to protect her, and therefore wanted nobody to meddle with her, much less an uncle who had never given her even so much as one bowl of flour since she was born.
title: Three Years in Tibet
author: Kawaguchi, Ekai, 1866-1945

quoteFirst: On the 23d, after we had put our ship to rights, we stood in for the harbour where the Marquis was, distant about four leagues to the N.E. sending our surgeons on board the prize to dress her wounded men. We same to anchor in the harbour
quoteTime: about four p.m.
quoteLast: where we received the compliments of all on board the Marquis on our sudden and almost unlooked-for success, which gave us all much satisfaction. We found that ship in good condition and ready to sail, and all on board her in high spirits, eager for action.
title:
A General History and Collection of Voyages and Travels — Volume 10
Arranged in systematic order: Forming a complete history of the origin and progress of navigation, discovery, and commerce, by sea and land, from the earliest ages to the present time.
author: Kerr, Robert, 1755-1813

quoteTime: about 4 P.M.

title: A Company of Tanks
author: Watson, William Henry Lowe, 1891-1932

quoteFirst: The island is still in its winter garb; not a bud has burst into leaf, and very few migratory birds have made their appearance. At 10.30 a.m. we are steaming out of the harbour; no wind, water smooth as a lake; run pleasantly down the Straits of Juan de Fuca, and pass Cape Flattery
quoteTime: about 4 p.m.
quoteLast: Wind blowing unpleasantly fresh, and a heavy tumbling swell makes the ‘Panama’ disagreeably lively. Passengers rapidly disappear; various gulping sounds, heavy sighs, and impatient calls for the steward, tell clearly enough that the most terrible leveller next to death, seasickness, has begun its work below.
title: The Naturalist in Vancouver Island and British Columbia, Volume 1 (of 2)
author: Lord, John Keast, 1818-1872

quoteFirst: I left him to draw the proper and natural conclusion on the conduct he should pursue. This conversation passed one day at Versailles
quoteTime: about four o'clock in the afternoon
title: Court Memoirs of France Series — Complete

quoteTime: about four o'clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: , Ney and Maison got within sight of that village, which Napoleon had quitted in the morning. Tchaplitz followed them close. Ney had now only six hundred men remaining with him.

History of the Expedition to Russia
Undertaken by the Emperor Napoleon in the Year 1812
author: Ségur, Philippe-Paul, comte de, 1780-1873

quoteTime: about four o'clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: that the first German column tried to advance upon Bellevue from the northern end of the spur. They were caught in our barrage and shattered.
title: From Bapaume to Passchendaele, 1917
author: Gibbs, Philip, 1877-1962

quoteFirst: _Friday._--Nothing whatever happened; but it looked a little like rain, over the downs,
quoteTime: about four o'clock in the afternoon
title: Blackwood's Edinburgh Magazine, Vol. 60, No. 373, November 1846

quoteFirst: The first was addressed to Lord Algernon Hastings in London. The other was a brief note to Aunt Ella, informing her that a party of four would start for Boston on the morning train and that she might expect them
quoteTime: about four o'clock in the afternoon
title:
Quincy Adams Sawyer and Mason's Corner Folks
A Picture of New England Home Life
author: Pidgin, Charles Felton, 1844-1923

quoteFirst: No event of moment happened to her during the first day of her journey. In passing a small settlement known as Morgan's Range, which she did at
quoteTime: about four o'clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: , she took the precaution to sweep around it in a wide circle, as some of the most active and evil-minded tories in the state resided in that neighbourhood. Successful in making this circuit, she resumed the road upon which her course lay, still urging forward her faithful animal, which, though much fatigued by the rapidity of his journey, obeyed the word of his rider, as if he comprehended the importance of the message she bore.
title: The Last Penny and Other Stories
author: Arthur, T. S. (Timothy Shay), 1809-1885; Croome, William, 1790-1860 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: The three sovereigns of Russia, Austria, and Prussia had been present on the 27th at the battle on the heights of Nothlitz, but had retired as soon as they saw that the battle was lost. That very day General Moreau was wounded by a cannon-ball near the intrenchments in front of Dresden, and
quoteTime: about four o'clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: was conveyed to Nothlitz, to the country house of a merchant named Salir, where the Emperors of Austria and Russia had established their headquarters. Both limbs of the general were amputated above the knee.
title: Complete Project Gutenberg Collection of Memoirs of Napoleon
author: Various

quoteTime: about four o'clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: , we arrived in Oldenburg, and began our eight-mile march to Vehnemoor Camp, which is one of the Cellelager group and known as Cellelager VI. We were glad to dispose of our packs by loading them on a canal-boat, which we pulled along by ropes, and we arrived at the camp late in the evening.
title:
Three Times and Out
Told by Private Simmons, Written by Nellie L. McClung
author: Simmons, Mervin C.; McClung, Nellie L., 1873-1951

quoteFirst: It will be years before these parts of New Guinea are surveyed. With one or two narrow escapes we managed to keep clear of the hidden dangers and at
quoteTime: about four o'clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: were in sight of the Trobriands. Knowing that our cutter "_A----s_" was sure to have called at Lagrandiere, one of the islands of the group, we determined to visit it, hoping by good luck either to meet her there or learn her whereabouts.
title:
Two Years Among the Savages of New Guinea.
With Introductory Notes on North Queensland.
author: Pitcairn, W. D.

quoteTime: about four o’clock in the afternoon

quoteFirst: It then fell a sheet calm, and the stranger at that hour might have been about five miles astern of us. It was
quoteTime: a little after four in the afternoon
quoteLast: . The heat was fierce. The planks of the deck burnt like hot furnace-bricks through the soles of the shoes, the pitch bubbled between the seams, and in the steamy vapor that rose from the brig’s sides the lines of her bulwark rails snaked faking to her bows as though they were alive.
title: List, Ye Landsmen! A Romance of Incident

quoteLast: , I was startled by the baying of bloodhounds behind me, and apparently on my track. Before escaping from jail, I had been advised by the prisoners to obtain some onions, as these, rubbed on the soles of my boots, would destroy the scent.

quoteFirst: I once found them together in the billiard-room, standing close together near the billiard-table; they seemed startled, and I apologised and left. In 1867 and 1868 the Prince of Wales called at Sir Charles's London house--in 1868 about once a week; but one week twice. He came
quoteTime: about four p.m.
quoteLast: , and stayed from one to two hours. I received him. Sir Charles was then at the House of Commons, or out pigeon-shooting.
title: Palace and Hovel; Or, Phases of London Life
author: Kirwan, Daniel Joseph

quoteFirst: A receipt, in Russian, was finally given us for our confiscated belongings, and
quoteTime: about four in the afternoon
quoteLast: , ten hours since we had eaten and five after our arrival, we were at last allowed to drag our shivering frames away in quest of lodging. There are no hotels in Urga, and visitors must appeal to the hospitality of one or another of the stray Europeans living there, of whom, excepting of course the numerous Russians, there seemed to be a single sample of each nationality.
title: Wandering in Northern China
author: Franck, Harry Alverson, 1881-1962 [Adapter]
